tucumcari new mexico  municipal code ____________ a codification of the general ordinances of tucumcari new mexico ____________ beginning with supp no 18 supplemented by municipal ____________ preface the tucumcari new mexico municipal originally published by book publishing company in 199 has been kept current by regular supplementation by matthew bender & company inc its successor in interest beginning with supplement no 18 municipal will be keeping this by regular supplementation during original codification the ordinances were compiled edited and indexed by the editorial staff of book publishing company under the direction of jeannette maddaford city clerk the code is organized by subject matter under an expandable threefactor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions each section number designates in sequence the numbers of the title chapter and section thus located in of title 2 in most instances sections are numbered by tens 010 020 030 etc leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions similarly chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion in parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section this legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table following the text of the code listing by number all ordinances their subjects and where they appear in the codification  and beginning with supplement no 18 legislation can be tracked using the table and disposition list a subjectmatter index with complete crossreferencing locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers this supplement brings the to date passed  municipal capital circle sw tallahassee fl 32310 8002622633 how to use your code this code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials city employees and private citizens please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code numbering system the numbering system is the backbone of a ordinances  municipal uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this is based on three tiers beginning with title then chapter and ending with section each part is represented in the code section number for example in of title 2 title a title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled this code contains about 15 to 20 titles for example the first title is title 1 general provisions which may contain ordinances about the general penalty code adoption and definitions the titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference some titles are reserved for later use deal with more specific subjects and are often derived from one ordinance all of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title the chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material for example city manager can be added between 204 city council and city attorney section of the code contains substantive ordinance material the sections are numbered by tens to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering tables of contents there are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information at the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title in addition each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections respectively note at the end of each code section you will find an ordinance history note which lists the underlying ordinances for that section the ordinances are listed by number section if applicable and year example  1992 beginning with supplement no 18 a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end these history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index statutory references the statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality as the statutes are revised these references will be updated crossreference table when a code is based on an earlier codification the crossreference table will help users find older or prior code references in the new code the crossreference table is located near the end of the code under the tabbed divider tables this table lists the prior code section in the column labeled prior  and the new code section in the column labeled herein as of supplement no 18 this table will no longer be updated disposition table to find a specific ordinance in the code turn to the section called tables for the disposition table this very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code the table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance if the ordinance is codified the chapter or chapters will be indicated example 204 612 904 if the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified such as budgets taxes annexations or rezones the disposition will be special if the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code usually at the direction of the municipality the disposition will be not codified other dispositions sometimes used are tabled pending number not used or missing beginning with supplement no 18 this table will be replaced with the table and disposition list table and disposition list beginning with supplement no 18 a table and disposition list has been added for use in tracking legislative history located in the back of this volume this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification the table and disposition list specifies the ordinance number adoption date description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance by use of the table and disposition list the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein index if you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code start with the index this is an alphabetical multitier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference and crossreferences where necessary look for the main heading of the subject you need then the appropriate subheadings business license see also business tax fee  required when  the index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended instruction sheet each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an instruction sheet the instruction sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement it will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current removed pages should be kept for future reference page numbers when originally published this code was numbered with consecutive page numbers as of supplement no 18 when new pages are inserted with amendments the pages will follow a point numbering system example 32 321 322   33 backs of pages that are blank in codes that are printed doublesided will be left unnumbered but the number will be reserved for later use electronic submission in the interests of accuracy and speed we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible we can accept most any file format including word wordperfect or text files if you have a choice we prefer word any version you can send files to us as an email attachment by ftp on a diskette or cdrom electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is errorfree our email address is ords@municodecom for hard copy send two copies of all ordinances passed to municipal po box 2235 tallahassee fl 32316 customer service if you have any questions about adoption there is adopted the tucumcari municipal  as compiled edited and published by book publishing company seattle washington  1999   titlecitationreference this code shall be known as the tucumcari municipal  and it shall be sufficient to refer to such code as the tucumcari municipal  in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity it shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to amendment to correction or repeal of the tucumcari municipal may be made to the titles chapters sections and subsections of the tucumcari municipal such references shall apply to those titles chapters sections or subsections as they appear in the code  1999   reference applies to all amendments whenever a reference is made to this code as tucumcari municipal  or to any portion thereof or to any ordinance of the city of tucumcari new mexico codified herein the reference shall apply to all amendments corrections and additions heretofore now or hereafter made  1999   title chapter and section headings title chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern limit modify or in any manner affect the scope meaning or intent of the provisions of any title chapter or section hereof  1999   reference to specific ordinances the provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record which refer to or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within the code but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code  1999   ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code the last ordinance included in this code was passed  the following obligations the adoption of this code does not affect prosecutions for ordinance violations committed prior to the effective date of this code does not waive any fee or penalty due and unpaid on the effective date of this code and does not affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit posted filed or deposited pursuant to the requirements of any ordinance  1999   constitutionality if any section subsection sentence clause or phrase of this code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code contained within this code  1999 general provisions short title the ordinances embraced in this code constitute the tucumcari municipal  and may be cited as the tucumcari  amended during 1999 codification  prior code  111   definitions and rules of construction a in construing this code or any ordinance agent means a person acting on behalf of another business dealing with the public means such solicitations and transactions regularly engaged in for monetary or other consideration but does not mean isolated or casual business transactions in which the public is not invited or expected to participate and which are outside the scope of a persons regular business operation the city or this city means the city of tucumcari  this code or tucumcari  means the tucumcari municipal commission means the governing body of the city of tucumcari county means the county of quay day means the period of time between midnight and the midnight following daytime means the period of time between sunrise and sunset discriminate includes but is not limited to separate or segregate employee does not include any individual employed by his or her parent spouse or child or in the domestic service of any person employer means any person employing four or more employees in some kind of employment and any person acting in the interest of such employer but does not include a social or fraternal club not organized for profit employment agency means any person undertaking with or without compensation to produce opportunities to work or to procure recruit refer or place persons for employment guardian means a person having care custody and control of another person and having the duty to manage and control the person and property of the other person guardian includes parent housing includes any building structure or portion thereof used occupied intended arranged or designed to be used or occupied as the home residence or living quarters of one or more human beings or any parcel of land or portion thereof available for the construction of such building or structure labor organization means any organization existing and constituted for the purposes in whole or in part of collective bargaining or of dealing with employers concerning grievances terms or conditions of employment or for other mutual aid or protection in relation to employment lending institution includes any person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans minor means any person under age eighteen 18 years month means a calendar month nmsa means new mexico statutes annotated nighttime means the period of time between sunset and sunrise oath includes an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the words swear or sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed owner when used in relation to real property means any part owner joint owner tenant in common tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or of a part of such real property person means any corporation company partnership association or society as well as a natural person personal property means every species of property except real property as herein defined private property means all property not public property property means real and personal tangible and intangible property public property means all property used for a public purpose or as a place of public gathering owned or under the control of the united states of the state or any political subdivision or a religious charitable educational or recreational association real property means land tenements and hereditaments shall is mandatory and may is permissive state means the state of new mexico tenant or occupant when applied to a building or land includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land whether alone or with others written or in writing may include printing engraving or any other mode of representing words and letters excepting those cases where the written signature or mark of any person is required year means a calendar year masculine includes the feminine singular includes the plural words used in the present tense include the future tense unless otherwise provided in computing time the first day shall be excluded and the last included unless the last falls on sunday in which case the time prescribed shall be extended to include the whole of the following month b the above definitions and rules of construction apply unless otherwise provided or unless inconsistent with the intent of this code or any ordinance  1999  prior code  112   amendments any additions or amendments to this code shall be adopted as ordinances as required by state law and when passed in such form as to indicate the intention to make the same a part of this code shall be incorporated into this code so that reference to this code as the tucumcari municipal  or tucumcari  shall be understood as including such additions or amendments    severability the provisions of this code are declared to be severable unless otherwise stated in this code if any section provision or part of this code shall be held unconstitutional or invalid the remainder of this code shall continue in full force and effect it being the legislative intent that this code would have been adopted even if such unconstitutional or invalid matter had not been included therein it is further declared that if any provision or part of this code or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid the remainder of this code and the application of this code to other persons shall not be affected thereby    effect of repealing ordinances the repeal of any provision of this code shall not affect any right which has accrued any duty imposed any penalty incurred any action or proceedings as commended under or by virtue of the provision repealed or the tenure of an office of any person holding office at the time when such repeal shall take effect the repeal of any provision of this code shall not revive any provision or any ordinance theretofore repealed or superseded    violationsprosecution prosecution for violations of municipal ordinances prior to the effective date of this code shall be governed prosecuted and punished under the ordinances existing at the time such crimes were committed  corporate seal corporate seal the corporate seal of the municipality shall be as follows in the center the word seal around the outer edge the words the city of tucumcari new mexico shall be and is declared to be the official seal of the city  general penalty maximum penalty unless a lesser maximum penalty or a specific penalty is established by ordinance for a particular offense the maximum penalty for violation of any municipal ordinance shall be as follows a except for those violations of ordinances described in subsections b and c of this section a fine of not more than five hundred dollars $50000 or imprisonment for not more than ninety 90 days or both  b for violation of an ordinance prohibiting driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs a fine of not more than one thousand dollars $100000 or imprisonment for not more than three hundred sixtyfour 364 days or both  and c for violations of an industrial user wastewater pretreatment ordinance as required by the united states environmental protection agency a fine of not more than one thousand dollars $100000 a day for each violation  1999   1994   mandatory fees collected upon conviction in addition to any fine or imprisonment described in there is imposed upon any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance the penalty for which carries a potential jail term or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle the following mandatory fees a a correction fee of twenty dollars $2000  b a judicial education fee of two dollars $200  and c a court automation fee of six dollars $600 as used in this section convicted means the defendant has been found guilty of a criminal charge by the municipal judge either after trial a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere or has elected to pay a penalty assessment in lieu of trial part 2003  1998   1994   disposition and use of fees a all money collected pursuant to a shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used for 1 municipal jailer or juvenile detention officer training  2 the construction planning construction operation and maintenance of a municipal jail or juvenile detention facility  3 paying the cost of housing municipal prisoners in a county jail or detention facility or housing juveniles in a detention facility  4 complying with match or contribution requirements for the receipt of federal funds relating to jails or juvenile detention facilities  5 providing inpatient treatment or other substance abuse programs in conjunction with or as an alternative to jail sentencing  6 defraying the cost of transporting prisoners to jails or juveniles to juvenile detention facilities  or 7 providing electronic monitoring system b a municipality may credit the interest collected from fees deposited in the special fund pursuant to subsection a of this section to the municipalitys general fund c all money collected pursuant to b shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the judicial education fund and shall be used for the education and training including production of bench books and other written materials of municipal judges and other municipal court employees d all money collected pursuant to c shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the municipal court automation systems in the municipal courts the court automation systems shall have the capability of providing on a timely basis electronic records in a format specified by the judicial information systems council part 2003  1999   1998   1994   citation in lieu of arrest allowed when a the city commission finds that the adoption of procedures for issuance of citations for petty misdemeanor offenses in the city will increase the efficiency of processing violations of petty misdemeanors reduce manpower and cost and aid in the administration of justice b a tucumcari police department officer who arrests a person without a warrant for a petty misdemeanor committed in the city may at the officers discretion offer the person arrested the option of accepting a citation to appear in lieu of incarceration c a citation issued pursuant to this section shall contain the name and address of the cited person the offense charged and the time and place to appear unless the person requests an earlier date the time specified in the citation shall be a minimum of three days after the issuance of the citation the police officer shall explain the persons rights not to sign a citation the effect of not signing the citation the effect of signing the citation and the effect of failing to appear at the time and place stated on the citation d the persons signature on the citation constitutes a promise to appear at the time and place stated in the citation one copy of the citation to appear shall be delivered to the person cited and the police officer shall keep a duplicate copy which he shall file with the municipal court as soon as practicable e a citation issued pursuant to this section is a valid complaint if the person receiving it appears in municipal court f it is a petty misdemeanor for a person signing a citation not to appear at the time and place stated in the citation regardless of the disposition of the offense for which the citation was issued the written promise to appear may be complied with by appearance of counsel  1986   suspension probation and community service a upon a plea of guilty or a judgment of conviction for violation of a municipal ordinance the municipal court may suspend in whole or in part the execution of sentence or place the defendant on probation for period not exceeding one year on terms and conditions the court deems best or both b suspension of execution of the sentence or probation or both shall be granted only when the municipal judge is satisfied it will serve the ends of justice and of the public c the defendants liability for any fine or other punishment imposed shall be fully discharged upon successful completion of the terms of probation d the municipal court may as a condition of probation require the defendant to serve a period of time in volunteer labor to be known as community service the type of labor and period of service shall be at the sole discretion of the court  provided that any person receiving community service shall be immune from any civil liability other than gross negligence arising out of the community service and any criminal diversion program shall not be entitled to any wages shall not be considered an employee for any purpose and shall not be entitled to workmens compensation unemployment benefits or any other benefits otherwise provided by law as used in this subsection community service means any labor that benefits the public at large or any public charitable or educational entity or institution  1988   restitution for damages and costs due to violation of criminal code andor motor vehicle code a 1 policy and definitions it is the policy of this city that restitution be made by each violator of the criminal code and any article of the city relating to the operation of a motor vehicle within the activities or to the extent that the defendant is reasonably able to do so it is the public policy of the city to 1 make whole the victim of the crime to the extent possible  and 2 to remind the defendant of his or her wrongdoing and require him or her to repay the costs society has incurred as a result of his or her misconduct this section shall be interpreted and administered to effectuate this policy as used in this section unless the context otherwise requires a victim means any person or the city which represents its citizens who has suffered actual damages as a result of the defendants criminal activities b actual damages means all damages which a victim could recover against the defendant in a civil action arising out of the same facts or event except punitive damages and damages for pain suffering mental anguish and loss of consortium without limitation actual damages includes damages for the costs of incarceration including but not limited to the costs of medical care c criminal activities includes any crime for which there is a plea of guilty or verdict of guilty upon which a judgment may be rendered and any other crime committed after  which is admitted or not contested by the defendant d restitution means full or partial payment of actual damages to a victim or the city 2 if the municipal court exercises its sentencing options the court may require as a condition of release or probation that the defendant in cooperation with the court promptly prepare a plan of restitution including a specific amount of restitution to each victim and a schedule of restitution payments if the defendant is presently unable to make any restitution but there is a reasonable possibility that the defendant may be able to do so at some time during his or her probation period the plan of restitution shall also state the conditions under which or the event after which the defendant will make restitution if the defendant believes that he or she will not be able to make any restitution he or she shall so state and shall specify the reasons if the defendant believes that no person suffered actual damages as a result of the defendants activities he or she shall so state 3 the defendants plan of restitution shall be submitted promptly to the court the court shall promptly enter an order approving disapproving or modifying the plan taking into account the factors enumerated in subsection a4 of this section compliance with the plan of restitution as approved by the court shall be a condition of the defendants release or probation restitution payments shall be made to the city clerk unless otherwise directed by the court the court thereafter may modify the plan at any time upon the defendants request or upon the courts own motion 4 the court when determining or reviewing the defendants plan of restitution shall consider the physical and mental health and condition of the defendant his or her age his or her education his or her employment circumstances his or her potential for employment and vocational training his or her family circumstances his or her financial condition the number of victims the actual damages of each victim what plan of restitution will most effectively aid the rehabilitation of the defendant and such other factors as shall be appropriate 5 the clerk of the court shall mail to each known victim a copy of the courts order approving or modifying the plan of restitution 6 failure of the defendant to comply with subsection a2 of this section or to comply with the plan of restitution as approved may constitute violation of the conditions of release or probation 7 this section and proceedings under this section shall not limit or impair the rights of victims to recover damages from the defendant in a civil action however any restitution payment by the defendant to a victim shall be set off against any judgment in favor of the victim in a civil action arising out of the same facts or event b disposition and use of fees collected all restitution collected shall be deposited in a special restitution fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used only for the payment of costs expended on behalf of the city or victim c lien and foreclosure the reasonable costs to the city in the direct and indirect enforcement of the law against the defendant shall constitute a lien against the real property owned by the defendant the lien may be foreclosed in the manner provided in nmsa 1978  1994   incarceration a notwithstanding any other provision of this municipal code any person upon whom any fine or penalty is imposed may upon order of the court convicting him or her be committed to the county jail municipal jail detention facility or other place provided by the city of tucumcari for the incarceration of offenders until the fine or penalty is paid in full the period of incarceration shall not exceed sixty 60 days for any one offense except as authorized in subsection c of nmsa 1978 every person so committed shall work for the municipal corporation and such labor as his or her strength will permit within or without the jail or other place provided for the incarceration not exceeding ten 10 hours each working day each offender shall be credited with eight times the federal minimum wage per day in reduction of any fine the municipal judge shall impose court costs and fees as provided in for any conviction of person who violates municipal ordinances as provided herein  title 2 majority vote appoint a qualified elector to fill the vacancy until the next regular municipal election or any special election called in accordance with subsection b of the section at which time a qualified elector shall be elected to fill the remaining unexpired term if any b a special election for the purpose of filling a vacancy on the governing body may be called by the chairman with the seventh street ending at the intersection of west charles avenue and south seventh street  part 2002  1999 prior code  218  4272012   annual salary the municipal mayor shall receive an annual salary of five thousand eight hundred dollars $580000 per year the municipal commissioner shall receive an annual salary of four thousand six hundred dollars $460000 per year  2007  1232015 editors note adopted dec 3 201 shall become effective after the 2016 municipal election city manager appointment and qualifications the commission shall appoint by a majority vote of all members a city manager for an indefinite term of office and whose salary shall be fixed by the commission the manager shall be appointed solely on the basis of administrative qualifications and his or her selection shall not be limited by reason of former residence    powers and duties the city manager shall be responsible to the governing body for the proper and efficient administration of the municipal government the city manager shall a be chief administrative officer of the city  b enforce and carry out all ordinances rules and regulations enacted by the commission  c employ promote suspend and discharge subject to the provisions of  all persons including department heads engaged in the administrative service of the city  d prepare and submit to the commission an annual budget  e submit recommendations to the commission on all matters concerning the welfare of the city  and f have a seat but no vote at every meeting of the commission except when clearly undesirable or unnecessary the commission shall request the opinion of the city manager on any proposed measure considered by the commission the city manager may hold other nonelective offices of the city including the offices of city clerk and treasurer    vacancy in office or absence from the city if a vacancy occurs in the office of city manager as a result of death disability resignation or removal of the city manager the commission may appoint a person to serve as acting city manager for a period of time not to exceed ninety 90 days if the city manager is to be absent from the municipality for a period of more than seventytwo 72 consecutive hours he or she shall designate an employee of the administrative service to act in his or her stead such designation shall be in writing and shall be filed in the office of the city clerk    removal by a majority vote of all the members of the commission the city manager may be removed from office  1999 prior code  224   delivery of records any city manager who resigns or is removed from office shall immediately deliver to the city clerk all money records property or other things in his or her charge and belonging to the city  city clerk clerical officer of the commission the clerk shall a keep in custody all minutes ordinances and resolutions approved by the commission  b attend all meetings of the commission  c record all proceedings ordinances and resolutions of the commission  d furnish copies of municipal records upon request the clerk may charge a reasonable fee for the cost of furnishing copies of municipal records    appointment the clerk shall be appointed by the manager for an indefinite term and removable by the manager  city treasurer appointment the treasurer is an officer of the city he or she shall be appointed by the manager for an indefinite term and is removable by the manager the treasurer shall serve within the finance department and the same person may hold both the office of clerk and the office of treasurer  1999  prior code  241 new mexico the municipal judge shall hold court once each day at eight am on mondays inclusive and shall hold court on the first and third wednesdays of each month at three pm the municipal judge shall also fix the amount of bail for any person arrested for the violation of this code or any city ordinance and also shall fix the amount of bond on appeals to the district court from convictions for violations of this code or any city ordinance the amount of the bail to be in the discretion of the municipal judge this authority shall be in addition to the authority given to the desk sergeant or clerk at the tucumcari police department to fix bail for any person arrested for violation of a city ordinance and when the municipal judge is not available to set bail for a prisoner the municipal judge shall also set the day and time on which the person arrested and for whom bail is fixed in which to appear before the municipal judge for trial this authority and duty is in addition to that granted to the desk sergeant or clerk at the tucumcari police department  1999   prior code  259   failure to appear the municipal judge or police officer herein mentioned fixing bail shall set the day and time on which the person arrested and for whom bail is fixed in which to appear before the municipal judge for trial and any person failing to appear on the day and time stated shall forfeit the bond to the city and further may be fined by the municipal judge in a sum of not more than five hundred dollars $50000 or be imprisoned in the city jail for not more than ninety 90 days or be punished by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court  part 1999  prior code  2510   municipal judgefailure to comply the failure or refusal of the municipal judge to comply with the provisions of this code shall constitute misconduct in office and grounds for removal from office  fire department establishedpersonnel a a fire department of the city is established and shall consist of a chief two assistant chiefs secretary training officer and fire fighters the total number of fire fighters including the officers of the department shall not exceed twenty 20 b the chief shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and shall be removable by the manager    duties it shall be the duty of the fire department to a extinguish fires  b rescue persons endangered by fire  c resuscitate and administer first aid to persons injured in or about burning structures or elsewhere in case of emergencies  d promote fire prevention  and e unless otherwise provided enforce all ordinances and regulations relating to fires fire prevention and safety of persons from fire in theatres stores and other buildings open to the public    promulgation of regulations the commission by motion or resolution may adopt and change regulations governing the organization and operation of the fire department the manager at any time may recommend such regulations to the commission and any changes therein which he or she deems desirable    fire chiefduties the chief shall a be the director of the fire department  b be accountable to the manager for the personnel morale and general efficiency of the department  c direct the operations and have administrative supervision and control of the fire department subject to the rules and regulations thereof  d supervise the manner of handling fires personally whenever possible in order to minimize injury to persons and damage to property during the progress of a fire the authority of the fire chief in all matters connected with the management or direction thereof or the disposition of property endangered by it shall be absolute all orders issued by him or her on such occasions shall be respected and any fire fighter or citizen refusing to obey the same is guilty of a misdemeanor  e conduct suitable drills or instruction in the operation and handling of equipment first aid rescue work and salvage  conduct a study of buildings in the municipality establishment of fire zones water supplies and all other matters generally considered essential to adequate fire protection and safety of life and property from loss by fire  f assist the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause origin and circumstances of all fires  g inspect buildings and premises and serve written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate within a specified time any and all fire hazards that may be found for the purpose of conducting such inspection the chief or fire marshal may enter any and all buildings and premises within the municipality at any reasonable hour any person served with a notice to abate any fire hazard shall comply therewith and promptly notify the chief of the remedial measure taken  h keep complete records of all fires inspections apparatus and equipment personnel and other information concerning operations of the department he or she shall furnish the council with such information when requested and his or her records shall be open to public inspection at all reasonable times  i make a complete annual report to the commission within two months after the close of the calendar year together with comparative experience data for the previous year with any recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department  j demote dismiss or expel any officer or member of the department for neglect or refusal to perform departmental duties subject to the rights of any members so demoted dismissed or expelled as provided in title 2 of this code  k enforce or cause to be enforced all ordinances laws and regulations of the city and state insofar as they pertain to fire and safety  l appoint the assistant chiefs from the membership of the department  1999  prior code  614   fire fighters a qualifications and appointment fire fighters shall be appointed at such time and in such manner as the commission may deem necessary such appointees shall be ablebodied citizens residing within the city limits preferably property owners whose business activities are normally within the confines of the municipality and who have telephones in their homes b duty of members it shall be the duty of all members of the department under the control and direction of the proper officers thereof upon an alarm of fire being given to go to the place of such fire in the city and there to work and manage the fire apparatus under the direction of the chief or other officer being in control the members shall not retire therefrom except by permission of the officer having chief control thereafter the members of the department shall return all apparatus to its place of keeping and then and there leave the same properly housed and in condition ready for immediate use the chief of the fire department is authorized to suspend any member refusing to obey orders or for misconduct or for failure to perform his or her assigned duties at any fire or for failure to attend departmental meetings and he or she shall make a report of his or her action to the city manager for his or her further action thereon    interference with fire department it is unlawful for any person or persons to hinder delay or obstruct any member of the fire department while in the performance of his or her duties at any fire no person shall place on or about any fire hydrant any rubbish building materials fence or other obstruction of any character or hitch to any fire hydrant any animal or animals or fasten to any such hydrant any guy rope wire or brace or otherwise interfere with the fire department in the discharge of its duties    entry on adjacent property it shall be lawful for any fire fighter acting under the direction of the chief or another officer in command to enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property that is on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire and no person shall hinder resist or obstruct any fire fighter in the discharge of his or her duty as hereinbefore provided    equipment the department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and provide adequate fire protection recommendations for acquisition of necessary equipment and facilities shall be made by the chief and after approval by the council shall be purchased pursuant to the public purchases act all equipment of the department shall be safely and conveniently housed in such a place or places as may be designated by the commission no person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose nor shall any person wilfully take away or conceal any article used in any way by the department no person shall enter any place where fire apparatus is housed or handle any apparatus or equipment belonging to the department unless accompanied by or having special permission of an officer or authorized member of the department no fire apparatus or equipment shall be hired out or permitted to leave the fire station except in response to a call for aid at a fire within the corporate limits of the city or in response to a call for aid at a fire within a fire district described in    agreements with fire districts the commission may from time to time enter into agreements for the joint use of facilities buildings and equipment with fire districts organized under the laws of the state    fire protection outside the city the city is authorized to enter into agreements or contracts to furnish fire protection outside the municipality or to enter into mutual aid agreements the members of the fire department are authorized and directed to render fire fighting service to communities organizations owners or occupants of premises outside the corporate limits of the city such service shall only be rendered subject to the terms of the agreement or contract entered into by the city    vehicles of fire fighters each member of the department is authorized to have one vehicle owned by him or her designated as an authorized emergency vehicle pursuant to nmsa 1978 each member of the department owning a car upon designation of the car in writing shall be issued suitable insignia to be attached to the car the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle shall operate such vehicle in compliance with nmsa 1978 no person shall drive any vehicle over fire hose except from specific orders from the chief or other officer in charge where the hose is used amended during 1999 codification  prior code  6111   fire alarms suitable alarm systems arrangements or equipment shall be provided for use in turning in an alarm and for alerting department members to report to duty stations it is unlawful for any person to maliciously turn in or cause to be turned in a false alarm    compensation all volunteer fire fighters of the city shall be compensated according to the rates established by the city commission  28 part 1999  prior code  6113 library department tucumcari public libraryestablished the name of the right and responsibility for the utilization of appropriate firearms when absolutely necessary  1980   reserve officerstraining reserve officers shall receive training consisting of classroom and managementestablished there is established under the executive branch of the government of the municipality of tucumcari in accordance with articles 101 nmsa 197 as amended being laws 195 as amended a department of emergency management which shall consist of a a coordinator of emergency management who shall be appointed by the governing body of the city and subject to approval by the state director  b all other municipal officers and employees together with those volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during periods of emergency shall be considered as part of the emergency management organization of the municipality of tucumcari  part 1999   1994   purpose of emergency management organization the purpose of the emergency management organization is to develop and implement the municipal emergency management program and to coordinate the efforts of all municipal agencies and employees and nongovernmental agencies to prepare for and function in the event of emergencies endangering the lives and property of the citizens of the municipality of tucumcari new mexico it shall be the duty of the organization to coordinate the development of comprehensive emergency management plans for the effective employment of municipal resources to protect the lives and health of the citizens of tucumcari new mexico and the private and public property therein from the effects of natural or mancaused emergency events including acts of war and to coordinate the implementation of such plans during periods of emergency such plans shall be coordinated with those of quay county and in consonance with the state emergency management plans  part 1999   1994   emergency management coordinator the emergency management coordinator shall be responsible to the city manager for the organization administration and operation of the emergency management program of the municipality of tucumcari new mexico the coordinator shall coordinate the emergency management activities of all municipal departments and agencies and nongovernmental agencies when the city has jurisdiction and shall maintain liaison with and cooperate with the emergency management agencies of the federal government the state of new mexico and other political subdivisions therein the coordinator shall develop an organizational structure for the department subject to the approval of the city manager and governing body  part 1999   1994   appropriation of funds funds for necessary expenses and functions of the department of emergency management including salaries for approved paid positions shall be made available by the municipal council in accordance with nmsa 197 as amended being laws 195 as amended the coordinator shall prepare and submit to the council an annual proposed budget for emergency management expenditures and functions and shall indicate therein those amounts eligible for matching funds under the federal emergency management assistance program emergency management funds may be obligated by the coordinator only in the amounts appropriated and for the purposes authorized by the municipal council  part 1999   1994 personnel footnotes  1  editors note adopted aug 14 201 amended families or friends vendors consultants and clients  8142014 employment   equal employment opportunity it is the policy of the city of tucumcari that every hiring and promotion opportunity will be filled by the best qualified applicants based exclusively on jobrelated qualifications without regard to racecolor national origin sex religion age or any other nonjob related criteria the city provides equal employment opportunity to all applicants for employment and employees and will not discriminate on the basis of racecolor national origin sex gender sexual orientation and pregnancy religion retaliation on the basis of a person opposing an unlawful employment practice age veteran status or disability in any decision regarding consideration for employment duration of employment training opportunities transfer or promotion opportunities salary benefits or any other terms and conditions of employment it is the goal of the city to comply with the requirements of equal employment opportunity as established by federal and state law  8142014   reasonable accommodation it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide reasonable accommodation for any person who is an employee or an applicant for employment who has or who acquired a physical or mental impairment eg any physiological disorder disfigurement or anatomical loss or limitations or any mental or psychological disorder acquired as a result of illness accident or birth as defined by state andor federal law as having an impairment which limits one or more major life activities but whose experience education andor training enable the person to perform the essential functions of the job position descriptions will be developed for every position employed by the city the position description will define the essential functions elements and tasks of the position as well as the environment in which the job activities are performed it is the responsibility of the employee to request a reasonable accommodation from the employees department head and the human resources department  8142014   competitive hiring recruitment selection and appointment it is the policy of the city to hire the best qualified candidates for employment with the goal of continuously improving the citys operations improving citizens satisfaction with the quality of services provided by the city and otherwise place applicants in jobs that best suit their abilities interests and skills when a position vacancy occurs the human resources director and the city managers office will conduct a recruiting and selection process designed to identify the best qualified and most suitable individual for the position unless compliance with the law or these personnel policies and procedures requires otherwise current city employees desiring to fill a vacant position shall be required to complete an application and shall participate competitively in the selection process it is the general policy of the city to accept the employment application as the only official instrument for employment consideration with the city rsums and other similar candidate profiles may be submitted but they will not replace the requirement of an official employment application signed by the applicant  8142014   ineligibility applicants or employees will be considered ineligible for hire or rehire by the city of tucumcari if the applicantemployee has 1 made any false statement or omitted any relevant information on the application for employment 2 not met the requirements of the position 3 failed to successfully complete the preemployment screening process 4 not been certified by a physician that the applicant can perform the physical requirements of the position 5 been previously dismissed from city employment as a result of a disciplinary matter or failure to successfully complete the introductory period 6 not a legal resident of the united states 7 been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor under the provisions of the criminal offender employment act nmsa 197 1013 1987 repl pamp 8 not met the criteria for bonding if required by the position 9 has had a dwi felony conviction andor reckless driving within the past three years the city manager has at his or her discretion the ability to waive any or all the above elements of ineligibility and to extend the probationary period to twelve 12 months for employees hired under this criteria  8142014   hiring temporary and casual employment in order to have the necessary flexibility in staffing to meet department demands seasonal or cyclical fluctuations in workload to temporarily replace employees absent due to termination or extended leave or to complete special shortterm projects the city manager may hire an employee noncompetitive selection process for a temporary or a casual job assignment see also classifications  8142014   hiring appointed employees appointed official ie the city manager is recruited selected and hired process determined at the sole discretion of the board of commissioners at the time of recruitment  8142014   preemployment screening the city of tucumcari is committed to a policy of hiring the best qualified available candidate to fill vacant city staff positions to accomplish that goal once the best qualified candidates for a position have been identified the city will conduct preemployment screening of those candidates in accordance with the procedure described below all applicants selected for hire shall complete a preexisting condition form pursuant to the workers compensation statutes nmsa 197  5211 et seq the human resource department will conduct a preemployment screening on every candidate prior to an offer of employment the nature of preemployment screening performed will vary depending on the requirements of the position being filled  certain positions have more stringent requirements than others uncertified or certified by waiver candidates for law enforcement positions will be required to successfully pass a physical agility test prior to employment every candidate selected for hire is required to pass a preemployment drug test prior to employment see drug and alcoholfree workplace section the cost of preemployment screening will be paid by the department that seeks to employ the applicant  8142014   probationary period every newly hired employee will serve a probationary period the purpose of the probationary period is to give the supervisor the opportunity to evaluate the employees suitability potential and performance in the position and to provide the employee the opportunity to decide if he or she is satisfied with the position the probationary period for employees except those hired as noncertified police officers is the first one hundred eighty 180 calendar days of continuous employment during this time all employees are on an introductory status are terminable at will and do not have access to the grievance resolution procedure with the approval of the city manager the probationary period for an individual employee may be extended for up to an additional ninety 90 calendar days employees cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedure set forth herein with relation to discipline or termination while serving the probationary period the probationary period for an employee hired as a noncertified police officer recruit will be extended as necessary to include the employees training at the law enforcement academy a recruit who fails to earn certification at the completion of training within the oneyear period required under new mexico law will be released from employment for failure to successfully complete the probationary period a recruit who successfully completes his or her training at the academy and attains certification will serve an additional 180day probationary period beginning on the date of certification a recruit may be terminated from employment for any reason while serving the probationary period any break in service or position transfer within the city shall require completion of a new probationary period upon rehire  8142014   employment classifications this policy establishes employment classifications in order to determine proper compensation administration working hour requirements eligibility for benefits and the application of other city policies the employment classification of each position within the city will be established by the city managers office based upon the specific job duties and responsibilities more than one status may apply to an individual employee regular regular employees are hired competitive hiring process to fill a position with a term greater than four months regular employees can work either fulltime or parttime and are eligible for employee benefits as described in the personnel policies and procedures temporary temporary employees are hired to fulfill specific requirements for limited periods of time not to exceed four months unless extended by the city manager for another ninety 90 days temporary employees can work on a parttime or fulltime basis are terminable atwill cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedures set forth herein do not receive city benefits and do not accrue leave casual casual employees are hired to fulfill specific requirements for limited hours of work on an intermittent basis over an extended period of time casual employees work on a parttime basis not to exceed nineteen 19 hours in any one work week on an intermittent basis over a period of a year or more are terminable atwill cannot avail themselves of the grievance resolution procedures set forth herein do not receive city benefits and do not accrue leave appointed the city manager is an appointed employee of the city the city manager is recruited selected and hired process determined at the sole discretion of the board of commissioners at the time of recruitment the city manager is terminable at will and cannot avail themselves of the grievance procedures set forth herein but are entitled to all other benefits provided by the city in accordance with the personnel policies and procedures except as stated otherwise fulltime fulltime employees are normally scheduled to work forty 40 hours per week or more they are eligible for all employee benefits time time employees are normally scheduled to work fewer than forty 40 hours per week employees accrue sick and annual leave at a reduced rate see annual leave section salaried salaried employees are paid a fixed salary amount for all hours worked in a pay period and perform work that is considered exempt under the provisions of the federal fair labor standards act they are not eligible for overtime pay for hours worked in excess of forty 40 in a work week hourly hourly employees are paid a specific rate for every hour worked employees in this category are nonexempt under provisions of the federal fair labor standards act and are eligible to be compensated for hours worked in excess of forty 40 in a work week contract contract employees are employees who are covered by the terms and conditions of their specific employment contracts in all cases where the personnel policies and procedures herein conflict with an employment contract the terms and conditions of the specific employment contract shall prevail minors refer to conditions stated at  all classification changes must be authorized on a personnel action form paf with proper signatures and submitted to the human resources so that a record is maintained in the personnel file employees shall report any name changes or changes of address to human resources as soon as possible  8142014   transfers and promotions in order to provide management the flexibility to accomplish departmentprogram goals and objectives and to give current employees the opportunity to apply their experience and education to a different position or to achieve a promotion the city of tucumcari may transfer employees to other duties in the departmentprogram or between departments with the approval of the city manager no employee has a right to any particular position within city employment the city manager may transfer an employee without loss of pay for any reason and that employee has no right to avail himself of the grievance resolution procedures  8142014   outside employment to give employees the opportunity to earn additional income without disrupting their employment with the city breaching the conflict of interest policy or any other policies herein the city of tucumcari has a policy to allow employees to engage in outside employment under certain conditions an employee may engage in outside employment however no employee may engage in outside employment which in any manner interferes with proper and effective job performance results in a conflict of interest or may subject the city to public criticism or embarrassment employees engaged in or wishing to engage in outside employment must first have the written approval of their immediate supervisor and the city manager a request that is denied is not grievable employees may engage in outside voluntary activities that are on an unpaid basis so long as those activities do not represent a conflict of interest impair their ability to perform their work or employ city assets and resources 1 no employee may engage in outside employment while absent from work using any leave benefits other than annual leave without prior written approval from the supervisor 2 the employee may not make material changes to such outside employment without the approval of their immediate supervisor and the city manager 3 an employee who engages in outside employment without approval may be subject to corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge  8142014   nepotism nepotism the showing of favoritism or giving preferential treatment to near relatives or to unrelated persons who are cohabiting based upon that relationship rather than on an objective evaluation of ability or suitability resulting in actual or perceived preferential treatment in the hiring appointment pay promotion transfers benefits and management of family members is prohibited near relatives for purposes of this policy are defined as employees spouse or exspouse children parents siblings grandparents grandchildren aunts uncles first cousins and like relations of the employees spouse this definition includes any person related to the employee by birth adoption or marriage this includes any person who would fall under the above definition if the persons who are cohabiting were in fact married near relatives will not be hired into a department where the employee directly supervises or is supervised by another immediate family member employees will not influence or participate in the hiring promotion transfers or management of near relatives if an employee is scheduled to be part of a panel interview for a near relative the employee will decline hisher involvement the supervisor will provide a substitute for that employee for that particular panel interview if employees become near relatives after employment and a conflict of interest or management problems of supervision safety security or morale result  or if a government operations reorganization creates such a conflict reasonable time may be provided to resolve the matter if a resolution is not possible the city may require one of those employees to be transferred or laidoff  8142014   employment of minors as a general rule employees of the city must be eighteen 18 years of age or older occasionally the city may hire students or others who are as young as fourteen 14 years old but this is done only under special conditions usually under the provisions of a grant agreement and must be approved by the city managers office in no case will minors be permitted to work in any occupation declared to be hazardous or detrimental to their health or wellbeing by the us secretary of labor minors younger than eighteen 18 years of age must provide a signed parental permission form to the city in order to work including a parental permission for the provision of emergency medical care  minors who are sixteen 16 or seventeen 17 years old may perform any nonhazardous job for unlimited hours  when school is in session fourteen 14 and fifteen 15 year olds may work up to three hours per day on school days including fridays  they cannot work more than eighteen 18 hours per week in school weeks  more than eight hours a day on nonschool days  or more than forty 40 hours per week when school is not in session  fourteen 14 and fifteen 15 year olds may not work before  am or after  pm except from june 1 day when their permissible hours are extended to  pm under a special provision fourteen 14 and fifteen 15 year olds who are enrolled in an approved work experience and career exploration program may be employed for up to twentythree 23 hours during school weeks and three hours on school days including during school hours wages andor stipends will be determined as provided in the grant agreement and approved by the city managers office students andor minors who hold stipend assignments must satisfy the training program requirements of the position and the conduct of the services to ensure compliance with the associated regulations for stipends all other positions for students are considered employment and associated tax withholding will be maintained  8142014   reductioninforce rif if it becomes necessary for the city to reduce the number of city employees because of economic conditions termination of a grant organizational changes lack of funds lack of work or other circumstances the supervisor may implement adjustments in staff levels by means of a personnel rif before instituting a rif the supervisor department head human resources department and city manager will explore reasonable possibilities for reassignment of affected employees and will consider requirements to maintain the citys operations selection of employees to be rifd will be done without regard to the employees racecolor national origin sex gender sexual orientation and condition of pregnancy religion age disability or any status protected by law the city managers office andor human resources department will provide assistance throughout the rif process to accomplish any possible interdepartment transfers of personnel and communication the city manager shall have final approval on all rif  8142014 compensation   compensation administration no employee will be paid less than the applicable legal minimum wage the city strives to pay salaries that are internally and externally equitable and to provide fair and competitive pay for work performed in order to accomplish this goal each job or position within the city of tucumcari has been formally described in a written position description that describes in summary form the purpose of the position the essential duties and responsibilities of the position the supervision given and received the minimum qualification standards that must be met by a candidate for employment to be hired for the position the physical demands of the position and the typical work environment experienced when performing the work based on the position description each position has been evaluated on objective factors with consideration given to current competitive labormarket conditions and assigned to a pay grade which establishes the value of the position in relation to other positions in the organization starting salary determination of the specific starting salary will be based on previous experience knowledge skills abilities and education consideration must also be given to current employees in the position their experience qualifications and pay internal fairness is important to reflect comparable pay for comparable skills responsibilities and objectives starting salaries will be determined in consultation with the city manager prior to making the job offer wage increase through the citys annual budgeting process depending on the availability of funds the board of commissioners may approve a wage increase for all employees when such an increase is approved it will become effective for each employee after final budget approval of the department of finance administration and the city manager employees on probation may be eligible for a wage increase upon completion of the probationary period with the city managers approval performance based increase performance based increases are related to the achievements and contributions of the employee as determined during the annual performance evaluation see performance appraisal section along with business considerations and conditions  budgetary constraints will also affect such decisions performance based increases if awarded are generally provided for in amounts determined citys annual budgeting process when budgeted funds are available the supervisor may recommend a salary increase by completing a recommendation form and submitting it along with a copy of the employees performance appraisal form to the city manager for approval compensation changes will generally be effective on the first pay period following the city managers approval certification increases employees who receive approved certifications for their department will receive a five percent increase effective at the start of the next pay period following submittal to the human resources department promotional increases when an employee is transferred or promoted salary changes associated with the move are generally granted immediately upon the effective date of the change of position see transfers and promotions section the amount of a compensation adjustment is determined by the city manager in comparison to other incumbents for internal equity and the budget for compensation approved for the department concerned employees who are placed in an interim or acting position are not automatically entitled to an increase in salary this decision will be made by the city manager on a casebycase basis if the employee receives an increase it will be considered temporary and will cease with the conclusion of the interim appointment loss of an interim appointment and any raise in pay accompanying the appointment are considered temporary and are not grievable the interim employee retains whatever employment status he or she had prior to the appointment to an interim position  8142014   employee performance evaluations it is the policy of the city that each employees job performance will be evaluated formally on an annual basis evaluations are conducted by the employees supervisor the performance evaluation will be conducted objectively and constructively on the basis of departmental and program mission goals and objectives position responsibilities and the employees annual performance plan see procedure the employees performance evaluation is the most important consideration when decisions regarding performance based merit increases are made evaluations do not automatically result in salary increases no discussion of compensation will occur during the performance evaluation all employees will receive a formal performance review upon the successful completion of their introductory period and annually thereafter on their anniversary date see compensation administration section  8142014   work schedule the city of tucumcaris normal workday is  am to  pm with one hour for lunch other regular hours may be established by the city manager or upon request from the department head to meet the departments needs once established the work schedule will be adhered to on a consistent basis lunch breaks and other office absences are to be coordinated with other staff and management when necessary to maintain coverage of services employees who work an eighthour day will have two fifteenminute breaks each day  one break will be scheduled at midmorning and the second will be scheduled at midafternoon the scheduling of break and meal periods is the responsibility of the supervisor who will ensure that proper coordination occurs so that business operations are maintained  8142014   pay period work week and paycheck employees of the city of tucumcari are paid every two weeks on the friday following the end of the pay period the payroll period consists of two consecutive work weeks if a payday falls on one of the holidays observed by the city of tucumcari employees will receive pay on the last working day before the holiday the work week of the city of tucumcari consists of seven consecutive 24hour periods beginning at  am on tuesday and ending at  midnight on the following monday all employee paychecks will be distributed deposit employees will designate on a form provided by the human resource department the bank and the account numbers where they want their paycheck deposited employees may change their designated bank and accounts at any time by contacting the human resource department and completing another form if an employee discovers an error in their paycheck he or she must notify their supervisor immediately the supervisor will investigate the error and contact the payroll office the payroll office will review the information and make any necessary adjustments adjustments will generally be made on the next paycheck if no adjustment is necessary an explanation will be provided to the employee  8142014   oncall and callback pay some employees of the city by the nature of their duties are oncall to respond to emergencies that may arise outside of normal working hours employees will be notified of their oncall status by their supervisor oncall employees are required to report to the scene of the emergency within thirty 30 minutes of being called other response requirements may be established by the supervisor and approved by the department head to meet the needs of specific departments oncall employees will be provided a cell phone to be used while oncall hourly employees required to be on call for five consecutive days shall receive eight hours of compensation at their applicable overtime rate of pay hourly employees who are called back to work outside of their regular work day will be paid for all hours actually worked at their regular rate of pay unless they qualify for overtime for which they will be paid time and a half if no work is available after an employee responds to a call the employee will receive not less than one hours pay for responding failure of the oncall employee to respond to a call may result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge  8142014   timekeeping all employees are required to complete a time sheet for each week of work including exempt employees the time sheets are to be completed showing all actual hours worked and all compensated timeoff such as annual leave sick leave holiday etc the time sheet will be signed by both the employee and the supervisor 1 employees are responsible for submitting accurate time sheets including all annual leave holiday or other paidunpaid leave forms taken in a pay period falsifying any time record is prohibited 2 employees will sign their own time sheet for each pay period and give it to their supervisor an employee is not permitted to record time for another employee any employee intentionally reporting time not worked whether for himself or for another employee will be subject to discipline up to and including discharge 3 supervisors will review their employees time sheets for accuracy and sign them before forwarding them to the payroll office 4 time sheets are due in the payroll office by monday at  noon after the end of the pay period when one of the holidays observed by the city falls on a date the time sheet is due the time sheet due date will be moved ahead by one working day the city managers office will provide advance notice of changes in the time sheet due date 5 exempt employees will keep track of their hours so that the city can keep a record of the employees use of sick and annual leave an exempt employee who takes leave of less than four hours at a time will not lose compensation as a result time off in excess of four hours shall be designated as sick or annual leave as appropriate  8142014   overtime overtime for purposes of this policy is defined as those hours worked in excess of forty 40 in any one work week by an hourly nonexempt employee all overtime must be approved by the employees supervisor before the work is performed failure to obtain authorization to work overtime may be grounds for disciplinary action overtime work should not be approved unless funds are available see also time off section overtime compensation unless compensatory timeoff is offered see below will be paid to hourly employees according to the following  hourly employees will be paid one and onehalf times their regular hourly rate for hours worked in excess of forty 40 in one work week  the minimum overtime that will be compensated is fifteen 15 minutes  only hours actually worked will be used to calculate overtime pay paid time off for annual leave sick leave jury duty management initiated work release or any other type of leave will not be considered as hours worked  overtime for hourly paid police officers fire fighters paramedics and emts will be calculated based on the special rules provided for these occupations by the us department of labor and the provisions of k of the us fair labor standards act  premium pay for overtime will not be pyramided an hour compensated at the overtime premium rate will not be counted again for the payment of premium pay for any other reason  8142014   compensatory timeoff at the discretion of the supervisor hourly employees may be granted paid time off compensatory or comp time in lieu of receiving pay for overtime worked procedure 1 when it is necessary that an employee work overtime see overtime policy the supervisor may choose to compensate the employee for the overtime worked by granting compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay 2 compensatory time earned will be reported on the employees time sheet submitted for the week 3 when granted compensatory time will be earned at the rate of one and onehalf hours for each hour of overtime worked 4 hourly paid police officers fire fighters and emergency medical personnel may accrue a maximum balance of two hundred forty 240 hours of compensatory time all other hourly employees may accrue a maximum balance of one hundred twenty 120 hours of compensatory time 5 compensatory time off may be used in the same manner as annual leave see leave section 6 unused accumulated compensatory time off will be paid out to the employee when his or her employment terminates 7 compensatory timeoff cannot be transferred to another employee  8142014   pay for travel time all payments of per diem and mileage allowance to city employees will be made pursuant to policies established by the state of new mexico in no event shall any mileage be paid for travel by a city employee in connection with the employees regular job duties within the boundaries of the city of tucumcari without the express written consent of the department head  8142014   termination administration it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to administer terminations of employment consistently and ensure that terminating employees receive required benefit continuation notifications and a timely issuance of their final paycheck and accrued benefits termination includes voluntary resignations and disciplinary discharge two consecutive days of failing to report for work without notification to the supervisor will be treated as a voluntary resignation see attendance section when an employee resigns from employment the employee shall give at least two weeks advance notice to their immediate supervisor to ensure the timely processing of
