the termination and issuance of a final payroll check failure to provide advance notice may preclude the rehiring of the employee in the future the city reserves the right to accelerate the final day of employment when accepting an employees resignation but the employee will be paid resignation date or the actual last day of work whichever is later  8142014   payroll deductions the city is required by federal and state law to make certain deductions or withholdings from employee pay only the deductions required by law or city policy or authorized by the employee will be made from payroll checks such deductions may include but are not limited to the following  federal income tax act fita  federal insurance contributions act fica  social security and medicare  state income taxes  group insurance premium if applicable or other insurance selected by the employee  public employees retirement association contributions  public employees retiree health care  other reimbursements as permitted by law  wage garnishments tax levies marital settlement agreements child support etc  other deductions as requested by the employee and approved by the city manager or required by law or city policy  8142014 attendance and timeoff   attendance unexpected absences from work and tardiness in reporting to work disrupt the citys ability to deliver the high quality of service its citizens expect in order to minimize these disruptions in service delivery and to ensure a productive and efficient work effort the city has established the following attendance policy and procedures when unexpected situations come up occasionally which may require an employee to be absent from work the employee must notify their supervisor within thirty 30 minutes of their regularly scheduled starting time that he or she cannot report for work or needs to leave the worksite early notification to a person other than the immediate supervisor when that supervisor is at work is not acceptable and is cause for disciplinary action up to and including discharge in the rare instances when employees are unable to report to work as scheduled or know they will be late they must notify their supervisor within thirty 30 minutes of the start of the regularly scheduled work day if an employee must leave work early they must notify their supervisor as soon as possible irregular attendance excessive absenteeism repeated tardiness or absence without notice is cause for disciplinary action up to and including discharge if an employee is unable to provide notice the employee is responsible for having someone do it for them when calling in absent every employee must a state the reason for the absence personal illness transportation etc b leave a phone number where he or she can be reached c notify the supervisor when they can be expected to report back to work d employees will maintain daily contact with their supervisor for any period of absence beyond one day unless he or she has provided a health care providers certification covering a specified period all personal and health care provider appointments should be scheduled whenever possible to accommodate the citys established working hours an employee who is absent for two consecutive work days without providing proper notice is considered to have voluntarily resigned his or her job  8142014   holidays and holiday pay the city observes the following fullday holidays and halfday holidays per year the city commission may declare additional days to be observed as city holidays to commemorate special events the designated holidays are new years eve december 31st halfday new years day january 1st martin luther king day 3rd monday in january presidents day 3rd monday in february good friday halfday memorial day last monday in may independence day july 4th labor day 1st monday in september veterans day 2nd monday in november thanksgiving day 4th thursday in november the day after thanksgiving day christmas eve day december 24th christmas day december 25th when a holiday falls on a sunday it is officially observed the following monday when a holiday falls on a saturday it is officially observed on the preceding friday employees eligible for the holiday pay benefit will receive holiday pay at their regular straight time hourly rate for a maximum of four hours on halfday holidays and eight hours on full day holidays time employees will receive holiday pay at a regular rate of fifty 50 percent per recognized holiday hourly employees required to work on an official city holiday will be paid at regular time unless they qualify for overtime casual and temporary employees are not entitled to holiday pay in order to receive pay for a holiday an employee must have worked on their last regularly scheduled day of work preceding the holiday and their next regularly scheduled day of work following the holiday paid leave scheduled in accordance with the citys leave policy will satisfy this requirement if a regularly scheduled holiday falls during an employees requested annual leave time the day will be paid as a holiday and not as annual leave an employee who terminates employment or commences an unpaid leave of absence on the last scheduled workday preceding a holiday will not receive holiday pay  8142014   annual leave the city of tucumcari provides its employees the opportunity to earn paid time off from work in the form of an annual leave benefit annual leave is earned on a prorata basis each pay period general provisions annual leave must be approved by the employees supervisor before being taken hourly employees may use annual leave in hourly or daily increments salaried employees may use annual leave in half or fullday increments annual leave timeoff will not be granted in advance of accrual employees will be paid for unused accrued annual leave upon termination pay will be computed based on the rate earned by the employee at the time of termination annual leave accrued during the probationary period will not be paid to an employee terminated during the probationary period annual leave accrual fulltime hourly employees are eligible to accrue 37 hours of annual leave per pay period for an annual total of 962 hours until they have reached their tenth anniversary date accrual begins on the employees date of hire and newly hired full time hourly employees will be credited with 37 hours of annual leave at the end of their first pay period after ten 10 years of service hourly employees are eligible to accrue  hours per pay period for an annual total of one hundred twenty 120 hours leave until they have reached their twentieth anniversary date after twenty 20 years of service fulltime hourly employees are eligible to accrue  hours of annual leave per pay period for an annual total of one hundred sixty 160 hours fulltime hourly employees will accrue annual leave during the probationary period but cannot use annual leave until they have completed the probationary period hourly employees may carryover a maximum of one hundred twenty 120 hours of annual leave from one year to the next hours in excess of one hundred twenty 120 accrued but not used by the final pay period of the year which includes december 31 will be forfeited fulltime salaried employees are eligible to accrue  hours of annual leave per pay period until they reach their tenth anniversary date beginning with the first pay period following their tenth anniversary date fulltime salaried employees will accrue  hours of annual leave each pay period fulltime salaried employees are eligible to carryover not more than one hundred sixty 160 hours of annual leave from one year to the next annual leave in excess of one hundred sixty 160 hours accrued and not used by december 31 of each year will be forfeited time hourly employees who work twenty 20 hours per week or more will accrue 185 hours of annual leave per pay period annual leave time is not earned during an unpaid leave of absence accrual resumes upon return to active status accrual is effective for every week that an eligible employee receives compensation for all regularly scheduled hours of work annual leave accrued as of  shall be retained by the employee and the recordkeeping for such accrued leave shall be kept separate from the accrual records maintained after that date casual or temporary employees do not accrue annual leave leave transferpayout an employee whose employment with the city is terminated shall be paid for unused accrued annual leave and comp time if the effective date of termination is before the end of a pay period no leave will be credited for that pay period  8142014   sick leave the city of tucumcari provides paid sick leave timeoff to employees to allow employees to accumulate time off with pay to take care of themselves due to shortterm illness or injury or to take care of an ill or injured immediate family member sick leave is provided to the employee to use for the following purposes  to recover from illness or injury which prevents the employee from working  for general healthmedical exams and treatment employee must provide documentation of appointment  for hospital stay or home bed rest ordered by physician  for dental or vision exams and procedures  for psychological examination and treatment includes related counseling  if the employees household is quarantined due to contagious disease of a resident member  to take care of a member of the employees immediate family see definitions and acronyms who is ill or injured abuse of sick leave may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination to request sick leave employees must notify their supervisor immediately upon knowing that sick leave is required if an employee is unable to provide notice the employee is responsible for having someone provide notice for them the employee must notify the supervisor of the following a the date the sick leave will begin  b documentation of medical need if will be absent three or more days  c the estimated date of return  and d a phone number where he or she can be reached employees will maintain daily contact with their supervisor for any period of absence beyond one day unless he or she has provided a health care providers certification covering a specified period salaried employees do not need to account for sick leave that is less than four hours at a time if an employee using sick leave is absent from work for three days or more employees must provide their supervisor a healthcare providers written statement as additional justification for absences of three days or longer for absences of three days or more for their own illness or injury employees must obtain and submit to their supervisor a healthcare providers written statement showing that the individual can return to work including any limitations or restrictions the employee may have employees who have a serious health condition may qualify for family and medical leave see  sick leave accrual fulltime employees accrue 37 hours of sick leave time per pay period time employees accrue 185 hours of sick leave per pay period accrual begins on an employees first pay period accrued sick leave may be accumulated from year to year casual and temporary employees do not earn sick leave leave transferpayout no payout of sick leave will be made at termination of employment upon retirement all employees who were employed by the city as of  will receive pay for onehalf of their accumulated sick leave at the time of pera approved retirement from the city the employee will be reimbursed for onesixth of the total sick leave accumulated in no event shall the employee be reimbursed for more than one hundred seventyfour 174 hours which is onesixth of the maximum accumulation allowed  8142014   donated leave in order to provide income protection for employees who experience a nonjob related seriously incapacitating and extended illness or injury leading to the exhaustion of all the employees appropriate paid leave balances the city provides a policy that allows other employees to donate some of their earned leave balances to the employee in accordance with the following provisions an employee who experiences a nonjob related seriously incapacitating and extended illness or injury and who has consequently exhausted all available leave balances may apply supervisor to the city managers office for donated leave not to exceed one hundred twenty 120 hours per occurrence requesting donated leave an employee wishing to receive donated leave will submit an application for donated leave to the supervisor and attach a statement from their physician that verifies the nature and expected duration of the condition in the event the employee is unable complete the application an authorized personal representative may submit the request on behalf of the employee the requesting employee must be an employee who is eligible to earn sick leave under the provisions of this personnel policies and procedures manual the application will be reviewed and approved by the supervisor the approved application will be forwarded to the city managers office the city manager will review the application and ensure that all applicable conditions are satisfied before approving the request once the request is approved the city managers office will communicate the employees request for donated leave to other city employees donating leave employees who have completed their introductory period and who wish to donate earned leave may donate either annual leave or sick leave the donating employee may only donate leave they have accumulated in excess of forty 40 hours the donating employee must maintain a minimum earned leave either annual leave or sick leave balance of forty 40 hours after the donation an employee who has an earned leave balance in excess of forty 40 hours and who wishes to donate leave to the requesting employee may do so by completing a donation of earned leave form the employee will indicate on the form the specific recipient of the donated leave the completed form will be forwarded to the city managers office and will be maintained there in confidence the city managers office will review all donations to ensure that all requirements for donating leave are met the office will accumulate the number of full hours donated deduct the donated leave from the balance of the donating employee and credit those hours to the leave balance of the requesting employee the office will maintain records to ensure that only the leave needed is used leave transferpayout donated leave time is donated and transferred to the requesting employee in fullhour increments only the requesting employee will be paid for donated leave at the pay rate of the requesting employee donated leave will be accumulated only to the extent needed by the requesting employee leave that is donated but not used will not be deducted from the leave balance of the donating employee no payout of donated leave is made at termination of employment procedure 1 in order to request donated leave the requesting employee must be eligible to earn sick leave in accordance with the sick leave policy 2 the requesting employee will complete an application for donated leave and attach a statement from their attending physician describing the nature of the injuryillness and the anticipated length of absence from work the application will be submitted to the employees supervisor if the employee is not able to complete the application a designated personal representative may complete it on behalf of the employee 3 the supervisor will verify the information contained in the application and indicate approval by signing the application and forwarding it to the city managers office 4 the city manager will review the application to ensure that all requirements of this policy have been met a if the city manager approves the application other employees of the city will be notified of the request for donated leave b if the application is denied the city manager will communicate the specific reasons to the requesting employee 5 employees who have completed their probationary period and wish to donate leave to the requesting employee and have more than forty 40 hours of accumulated earned leave see definitions and acronyms may donate leave in fullhour increments by completing a donation of earned leave form and submitting it the city managers office 6 the city managers office will ensure that all leave donations meet the requirements of this policy and will administer the deduction of donated leave from donating employees and the payment of leave to the requesting employee in accordance with this policy  8142014   leaves of absence to provide income protection for employees who must be away from work under certain circumstances and also to allow certain absences on an unpaid basis with no loss of accumulated service the city is committed to respecting the needs and desires of their employees for time off while balancing the needs of the citys operations leaves of absence may be granted to employees for the reasons specified herein and are available to employees who have completed their probationary period with the city unless otherwise noted abuse or falsification of leave time will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment paid leave offered under this section does not accumulate from year to year paid leaves of absences bereavement leave up to three eighthour days of paid leave may be granted for bereavement in the case of the death of a member of the employees immediate family see definitions and acronyms up to two eighthour days of paid leave may be granted for bereavement in the case of the death of an employees nonimmediate family members see definitions and acronyms hourly employees may use bereavement leave in hourly or full day increments salaried employees may use bereavement leave in half or fullday increments if the funeral for a member of the employees immediate family as outlined above is held out of town the employee will be granted additional paid time off one additional day with pay will be granted if the funeral is held more than three hundred 300 miles from the city of tucumcari  two additional days off with pay will be granted if the funeral is held more than six hundred 600 miles from the city of tucumcari the supervisor may also approve additional timeoff either as unpaid leave or the employee may use other earned paid leave at the time of bereavement personal leave a fulltime employee will be granted sixteen 16 hours of paid personal timeoff each calendar year an eligible employee who has completed the probationary period may use personal leave for any personal business personal leave may be used in increments of four hours and must be approved in advance by the supervisor personal leave not used by the end of the calendar year will be forfeited and may not be accumulated from year to year unused personal leave will not be paid out at resignation or termination voting leave an employee who is registered to vote will be allowed up to two hours of paid timeoff for purposes of voting in a national state or local election if the employees work schedule prevents them from voting before or after working hours such timeoff will generally be at the beginning or end of the regular working shift whichever allows the most free time for voting and the least timeoff from working unless otherwise provided by the employees supervisor this leave will not be granted to any employee whose work day begins more than two hours after the opening of the polls or ends more than three hours before the closing of the polls jury or witness duty leave employees who serve on a grand jury or a trial jury or who are subpoenaed to appear in court as a witness as required by law will be granted paid timeoff from work for the time the employee is actually required to be away from work those employees who receive paid leave must give any fee received to the city if they choose not to take paid leave they may keep any compensation received from jury service or witness duty if the employee is excused by the court during a working day the employee shall immediately return to work if at least one hour of the employees regularly scheduled work day remains to be completed time and temporary employees are not eligible for jury or witness duty leave employees must provide reasonable notice to their supervisor for days he or she will be absent and when he or she can be expected to report to work employees on jury or witness duty leave must call their supervisor at the commencement of each work day as per the attendance policy to notify the supervisor if the employee is to be on jury or witness duty that day the employee must provide their supervisor with a copy of the summons for duty or the subpoena united states military reservenational guard leave employees who are members of the united states military reserve or the national guard will be granted up to fifteen 15 days of paid timeoff during a one year period to attend military training drills encampment naval cruises and special duty or like activity  to be eligible for military reservenational guard leave the employee must provide a copy of the orders requiring the leave  united states military reservenational guard leave must be requested twenty 20 days in advance  for this period of service up to fifteen 15 days employee health benefits will be continued and the employee will not be required to pay more than the stated employee share of any premium inclement weather  the city manager may at hisher discretion close city offices and send nonessential employees home due to inclement weather the nonessential staff is paid as if they were at work  public works and public safety employees are expected to work  it is part of their responsibilities to always have staff for public safety and are paid at their normal rate of pay the street department must work on roads fire ems and pd must have staff available to respond to the public needs unpaid leaves of absence any employee who is granted an unpaid leave of absence will not accrue sick or annual leave during the period of absence military leave employees who enter the armed force of the untied states or who are members of the reserve corps of the armed forces of the united states or the national guard who are called up for active duty or special duty or like activity for more than fifteen 15 working days will be granted an unpaid leave of absence  to be eligible for military leave the employee must provide a copy of the orders requiring the leave  applicable laws will be observed regarding reinstatement at close of tour to be reemployed the employee must make application for reemployment within ninety 90 days after being released from duty or within ninety 90 days of release from hospitalization which continued after discharge for a period of not more than one year  the returning employee will be deemed to have accrued seniority and length of service rights as though his employment with the city had been continuous since his last date of hire with the city  the returning employee shall have all unused annual and sick leave accrued and not paid at the time the leave began restored continuation of benefits while on a leave of absence if an employee is granted an unpaid leave of absence the employee may continue group health insurance coverage city in conjunction with applicable federal cobra guidelines by making monthly payments as directed by the city managers office for the amount of the relevant premium return from a leave of absence prior to the end of the leave of absence the employee should notify his or her supervisor and confirm the date of return within a reasonable time frame when an employee is able to return from a leave of absence the city will make all reasonable efforts to reinstate the employee in his or her previous position and salary however it may be necessary to reassign the employee if the city no longer can accommodate the employee in the former job if reassignment is necessary the city will make every reasonable effort to place the employee in an equivalent position with similar duties pay and status failure to return from a leave of absence if an employee fails to return from a leave of absence on the scheduled date it will be considered a voluntary resignation of employment leave procedure 1 employees must submit leave requests to their supervisor using the appropriate form required supporting documentation will be attached to the leave request 2 the request will state the reason for the leave and the length of time the employee desires 3 the supervisor who has the authority to approve leaves of absence must sign the request for leave form leaves may be denied in cases where workload or grant objectives could be seriously affected 4 the supervisor will notify employees whether a leave request is granted or denied within one week of receipt of the written leave request 5 if a leave is granted the leave request form will be forwarded to the city managers office 6 if an employee needs an extension to the leave he or she must make the request in the same way as outlined in the steps above 7 employees must not accept outside employment or apply for unemployment insurance while on a leave of absence acceptance of outside employment while on leave will be treated as voluntary resignation from employment at the city 8 certain benefits such as employee insurance may not be paid by the city while the employee is on an extended unpaid leave of absence depending on the provisions of the benefit plan documents the employee should consult the city managers office for information unpaid leave will not count as time worked for the accrual of earned leave benefits 9 upon return from a leave of absence where possible employees will be credited with the full employment status that existed prior to the start of the leave except in the case that the leave extends beyond thirty 30 days when reinstatement may be affected if it is an undue hardship to fully reinstate the employee  reasonable accommodation will be applied whenever possible in such cases in the case of military leave applicable laws will govern reinstatement 10 if an employee fails to return from leave it will be considered a voluntary resignation  8142014   family and medical leave all employees who have worked for the city of tucumcari for at least twelve 12 months and who have worked at least one thousand two hundred fifty 1250 hours during the previous twelve 12 months will be eligible to receive up to sixty 60 work days comprising twelve 12 calendar weeks of unpaid family and medical leave during a twelvemonth period measured backward from the date the leave first commences for one or more of the following reasons newborn or newly adopted children eligible employees may request a family and medical leave of absence to provide care for a child following the childs birth adoption or foster placement in the employees home this leave must be taken within a year after the child is born adopted or placed in the employees home illness of a family member employees may request a family and medical leave of absence to provide care for a member of the employees immediate family who has a serious health condition a serious health condition is understood to be an illness injury impairment or physical or mental condition serious enough to involve hospitalization inpatient care in a hospital residential health care facility hospice or continuing treatment or supervision by a health care provider the city may require appropriate medical certification before a leave is granted illness of the employee eligible employees may request a family and medical leave of absence when the employee is unable to work because of their own serious health condition including pregnancy an employee who qualifies for fmla leave may be permitted to take a reduced schedule or take intermittent leave to tend to the employees medical needs or the needs of the family member the city will require an employee to use all of the employees accrued and unused annual and sick leave to cover the leavetime prior to going on unpaid leave all time taken off from work whether paid or unpaid will be counted against the remaining balance of family and medical leave once paid time off is exhausted family and medical leave will continue to the maximum allowable time off if needed an individual who is unable to return to work after all of their available sick leave andor family and medical leave is exhausted is subject to termination procedure application and commencement 1 a family and medical leave of absence fmla form must be completed and submitted to the employees supervisor thirty 30 days prior to the commencement date of the leave except where medical conditions make meeting such a requirement impossible 2 when the leave is to care for a family member the requesting employee must submit a letter signed by a physician that states a the date the illness or condition began  b the probable duration of the condition  c the estimated time the employee will need to care for the family member  and d a statement that the illness or condition requires the employee to provide such care 3 if the leave request is for the employees own serious health condition the medical certification must also state that the employee is unable to perform the essential functions of the employees current position 4 if the supervisor has any doubt as to the validity of the certification a second opinion may be required from a medical provider of the city managers choice and at the citys expense in addition the city manager may require that a third opinion be obtained from a health care provider at the citys expense in such an event the opinion of the third provider shall be final and binding 5 the fmla form and relevant medical certifications must be submitted to the city managers office for approval 6 when the leave is for planned medical treatment the employee must attempt where possible to schedule the treatment so as not to disrupt city operations 7 employees will be required to use available paid time off during the family and medical leave period reinstatement 1 upon returning from a family and medical leave that does not exceed the maximum eligible length of leave the employee will be reinstated to their original position held prior to commencement of the leave or to an equivalent position with no loss of seniority or benefits that accrued prior to taking the leave 2 employees on leave must notify their supervisor at least two weeks prior to the end of leave of their availability to return to work 3 a medical release to return to work from a leave taken for the employees own serious health condition will be required from the employees health care provider 4 an employees failure to return from leave or failure to contact his or her immediate supervisor or the city managers office on the scheduled date of return will be considered a voluntary resignation continuation of benefits 1 during an approved leave the city shall continue to provide if otherwise available medical coverage under its group health plan on the same conditions that would have applied if the employee had not taken the leave in no case will the city continue to pay for such coverage for more than the maximum eligible duration of the leave 2 the employee shall be responsible for paying the employees portion if any of the insurance premium including the premium for dependent coverage if available failure of the employee to pay these premiums on a timely basis may result in a lapse of coverage 3 if the employee fails to return to work at the end of the leave period the employee will be required to reimburse the city for group health insurance premiums paid by the city on behalf of the employee during the leave unless the failure to return is due to a continuation reoccurrence or onset of a serious health condition that entitles the employee to leave under this policy or due to circumstances beyond the employees control 4 no annual or sick leave will accrue while an employee is on a family and medical leave  8142014 discipline and rules   corrective disciplinary action the city understands that most employees are diligent dedicated and intent upon making a strong contribution to the success of the city for the purposes of achieving the citys mission goals and objectives this policy is a guide for correcting those instances of unacceptable work behavior or poor performance and providing employees the opportunity to succeed the city may proceed with suspension or discharge at any point in the corrective disciplinary action process at its sole discretion taking into consideration business necessity or the seriousness of the employee infraction administrative leave a under certain serious circumstances such as when a fight theft or other major behavior problem occurred it may be necessary to remove an employee from the workplace pending investigation or predisciplinary hearing and the determination of the final recommended disciplinary action in such cases the supervisor may place an employee on administrative leave with pay the department manager and the city managers office will be notified prior to an employee being placed on administrative leave b depending on the outcome of the investigation further disciplinary action may be imposed suspension and demotion if the employee continues to fail to meet expectations or is found to have violated policy but not to a degree that would warrant discharge the supervisor may recommend to the city manager that the employee be suspended or demoted a demotion is defined as a change in job responsibilities accompanied by a loss in pay a disciplinary suspensions will be without pay the suspension will be imposed for a specific length of time with a date of return to work suspension andor demotion are an attempt to correct inappropriate behavior of an employee before discharge before imposing a disciplinary suspension or demotion the employees supervisor will provide the employee with a written notice of intent to suspend or notice of intent to demote and will conduct a presuspension meeting with the employee where the employee has a chance to contest the suspension or demotion discharge under certain circumstances an immediate discharge may be appropriate examples of situations which may result in immediate discharge include but are not limited to the unlawful manufacturing distributing dispensing possessing or using of controlled substances or alcohol while on the citys premises or while on duty or reporting to work under the influence of an unlawful controlled substance or alcohol  theft  acts of negligence causing damage to persons or property  falsification of information on the employees job application or other city records  refusal or failure to comply with city policy  insubordination  disruptive conduct interfering with the citys operations  unauthorized use of city property facilities materials or other city assets for personal use  accepting gratuities  bringing unapproved weapons onto city property  conviction of a job related felony or misdemeanor as described in the criminal offender employment act nmsa 197  2821 et seq  actual or threatened physical violence towards another employee or a citizen customer  or any other conduct deemed not to be in the best interests of the city and its employees before imposing a discharge the supervisor will provide the employee with a written notice of intent to discharge the employee will then be allowed an opportunity to meet with the supervisor within three working days of the notice and will be given an opportunity to respond to the proposed discharge the supervisor will then make a final decision if discharge is recommended the discharge decision will be presented to the city manager for approval the discharge is not final unless approved by the city manager appeal regular employees who have successfully completed their probationary period and who receive a disciplinary suspension demotion or discharge penalty may appeal the action by following the grievance resolution section  8142014   drug and alcoholfree workplace it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a workplace reasonably free of known hazards the city views the use and presence of illegal drugs and the abuse of legal drugs and alcohol as extreme hazards to employees visitors customers and the community the city of tucumcari intends to ensure a drug and alcoholfree workplace to establish guidelines for responding to incidents of abuse of controlled substances and alcohol by employees of the city and to provide a safe and secure workplace for all employees visitors and guests this policy applies regardless of whether the employees conduct constitutes an illegal act or whether the employee in question is criminally prosecuted andor convicted for such conduct the city of tucumcari prohibits the unlawful manufacture use distribution possession or sale of any illegal substance in the workplace including illicit drugs and other controlled substances the city of tucumcari further prohibits the presence or use of alcohol by employees other than bartenders while at work or on city property except when attending sanctioned functions after hours at city facilities distribution of prescription drugs to others or use of those drugs in a manner other than as prescribed by a physician is similarly prohibited while at work or on city property reporting for work or conducting city business while intoxicated or under the influence of any illegal substance is expressly prohibited some programs departments andor positions must comply with the commercial drivers license cdl regulations supervisors will inform their employees and enforce these regulations if this is the case for positions requiring a cdl the city of tucumcari reserves the right to apply this policy in a manner appropriate and in support of the citys mission and values an employee who believes that he or she has a problem with alcohol or drugs that is interfering with their job performance is encouraged to voluntarily seek help before their substance abuse problem becomes the subject of corrective disciplinary action employees who violate this policy will be subject to corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge and may also be required to participate in a rehabilitation program of a type reviewed and approved by the city managers office failure to cooperate with or complete such a program may result in further corrective disciplinary action including immediate discharge employees participating in a rehabilitation program shall use available earned leave for which they are eligible when available earned leave is exhausted the employee may be eligible for unpaid leave upon request and approval by the supervisor returning to employment from leave may also be contingent upon the ability of the city to reasonably accommodate the employee in administering this policy the city managers office andor the supervisor will strive to maintain the employees status and any information regarding substance abuse in strictest confidence for purposes of this policy an illegal drug is any drug or druglike substance which is prohibited or restricted by law this policy prohibits an employees use or possession of the drug regardless of whether such conduct constitutes an illegal act or whether the employee is criminally prosecuted andor convicted for such conduct a legal drug is a drug which is prescribed by a physician or available overthecounter the city requires any employee taking legal drugs which may impair the employees ability to safely perform their job functions to report the use of the medication to their immediate supervisor the supervisor may assign other duties or grant sick leave timeoff if the employee is unable to perform hisher assigned duties or perform any duties in a safe manner if the use of a legal drug impairs the employees ability to safely perform the essential functions of the employees job transfer or even termination may be considered employee testing employees will be required to undergo drug and substance abuse testing upon the following conditions  preemployment the city will test all applicants who receive an offer of employment the city will revoke a job offer to any applicant who tests positive for any illegal drug  reasonable cause if the supervisor has reasonable cause see definitions and acronyms the employee will be required to submit to a substance abuse test  refusal to do so will be grounds for disciplinary action up to and including discharge when a motor vehicle accident occurs that results in injury to a person or damage to property it will be considered as reasonable cause for testing of the employees involved which may include a blood alcohol test  random employees who have had positive test results or who have been convicted of any criminal alcoholdrug statute will be required to submit to random substance abuse tests as a condition of continued employment whether or not they are involved in a rehabilitation process a positive test result during random screening will result in immediate discharge  jobspecific positions that by their nature can affect public safety including cdl operators will be designated as those requiring random testing after hire any such requirement shall be indicated in the position description  motor vehicle accidents an employee who is involved in a motor vehicle accident while on duty which results in property damage or personal will be tested in all circumstances regardless of fault testing procedures the city will determine the type and manner of drug and alcohol testing including what constitutes a positive test result at its sole discretion test samples will be collected in a reasonable and sanitary area and will be labeled and handled in such a way reasonably designed to preclude sample contamination adulteration or misidentification the city is entitled to rely on the results of its drug or alcohol testing to determine if any employee has violated this policy and is subject to corrective disciplinary action all drug or alcohol testing will be performed by a certified laboratory facility using scientifically accepted analytical procedures and meeting confidentiality requirements this facility has been identified and its name and address is on file in the city managers office positive results of alcohol and drug testing guidelines are established by the department of health and human services will be used to determine whether an employee test positive any employee who test positive for drugs or alcohol will be dismissed an employee has the right to have the original sample retested at the employees own expense inconsistent test results will be reviewed by the city manager who has the discretion to accept the retest results or to request an additional test the ultimate decision of the reliability of the results will be made by the city manager at the time of testing a person will be given the chance to provide any information that may be relevant to the test including whether the person is taking prescription or over the counter medication or undergoing any medical treatment that may affect the result of the test additionally individuals will be given the chance to explain a positive test result in a confidential setting threshold of positive results the positive results thresholds are as follows  alcohol a blood alcohol concentration of 002 except that for individuals holding a cdl as a job requirement any test greater than 000 is considered positive  illegal drugs current limits set by the us department of health and human services to indicate confirmed presence of the drugs  prescription drugs sample levels in excess of what would be expected by using the drugs as prescribed by the attending physician or where the drug has not been prescribed to that employee employee notice of conviction or arrest 1 any employee who is convicted of any criminal alcoholdrug statute must notify the supervisor within five working days of conviction conviction includes a finding of guilt a plea of no contest or an imposition of sentencing by any judicial body for such criminal drug statute violations 2 employees who are employed in safetysensitive positions as identified in their job descriptions must notify the supervisor within five working days of an arrest for a drug or alcoholrelated offense the city manager will decide whether the employees job duties will be modified and will take whatever action is deemed appropriate under the circumstances 3 the supervisor shall take the following action when such notice of conviction is received or when heshe receives any verifiable information relative to violation of the drug and alcoholfree workplace policy a notify the city managers office after receiving notice from an employee or otherwise receiving actual notice of a criminal alcoholdrug statute conviction b take appropriate personnel action if the employee is unable to perform his or her job duties as a result of the conviction c encourage according to circumstances such employee to seek rehabilitation in a substance abuse program procedure 1 employees are encouraged to seek voluntary treatment for substance abuse if an employee wishes assistance or referral information he or she should contact their supervisor and human resources 2 any employee who observes another employee violating this policy will notify the employees supervisor whose responsibility will be to verify the abuse observation if at all possible or assistance of other management depending upon the circumstances of the suspected abuse 3 if a reasonable cause is found the employees supervisor will require the employee to submit to substance abuse testing as provided in this policy 4 refusal by an employee to submit to a drug or alcohol test as required by the supervisor or testing positive for illegal drugs or alcohol will result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including immediate discharge for a first offense depending upon the facts and circumstances involved in each situation 5 the city managers office will notify the employee and the employees supervisor of the results 6 the supervisor will initiate disciplinary actions as appropriate  8142014   grievance resolution procedure it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a grievance resolution procedure to be followed exclusively for the resolution of disputes between a regular employee see employment status section excluding temporary and appointed employees and a supervisor that may arise over the suspension demotion or discharge of the employee any regular employee who has successfully completed the probationary period and who feels that he or she has been unfairly suspended demoted or discharged or who believes that mitigating facts may not have been fully considered before the suspension or discharge was administered may apply for reconsideration of that decision procedures provided in this policy temporary casual and appointed employees may not use the grievance resolution policy and procedure the following are not grievable  dismissal of probationary employees prior to the expiration of their probationary period  release of temporary or emergencyhire employees prior to or at the end of their anticipated employment period  dismissal of appointed employees at any point during their employment with the city  transfers temporary assignments removal from temporary assignments and promotions  job evaluations performance appraisals verbal or written reprimands or selection for vacant positions  matters where the city is without authority to act or does not have the ability to provide a remedy  failure by the employee to proceed to a higher step of the procedure within the time periods provided herein will terminate the grievance resolution process only the issues raised and presented originally for resolution shall be considered on appeal decisions rendered by the personnel hearing officer see procedure below may serve as precedents for the resolution of similar subsequent disputes procedure 1 the city manager or hisor her designee shall meet with the employee the employees supervisor and the manager of the department where the employee works the employee shall have the opportunity to respond to the proposed corrective disciplinary action provide physical evidence and provide any mitigating or exculpatory information 2 the city manager will issue a decision in writing or approve the written decision of his or her designee within five working days of the hearing 3 the employee may appeal the city managers written decision to the personnel hearing officer by submitting a written appeal and request for a postdisciplinary grievance hearing to the city managers office within five working days of the receipt of the city managers written decision 4 within ten 10 working days of receipt of the grievants appeal and request the city manager will provide the grievant with the name of the hearing officer the hearing officer shall be familiar with public andor private personnel systems or have pertinent experience in the appropriate areas of management or law qualifications for service as a hearing officer shall be verified by the city managers office the hearing officer need not reside in the city of tucumcari 5 the personnel hearing officer will determine the date time and location of the postdisciplinary hearing and grant continuances agreed to by both parties the hearing will be conducted at a time and place which is mutually convenient to all parties requests for continuances of hearings shall be made in writing to the hearing officer with a copy to the opposing party at least five working days prior to the scheduled hearing absent extenuating circumstances the hearing must be held within sixty 60 days of the receipt of the grievants appeal and request by the city manager the parties must agree in writing to any postponement of the grievance hearing beyond sixty 60 days notice of the hearing will be sent by certified mail to the grievant and postmarked at least ten 10 days prior to the scheduled hearing copies of the hearing notice will be sent concurrently to all relevant parties 6 postdisciplinary hearings shall be conducted as open meetings with notice given to the public pursuant to the new mexico open meetings act and the city of tucumcaris open meetings resolution the grievant shall have an opportunity to present witnesses and physical evidence and cross examine the citys witnesses before the hearing officer the grievant at his own expense may have legal counsel represent him at the hearing the city may have legal representation at the hearing even if the grievant is not represented by counsel 7 the personnel hearing officer shall determine the order of agenda items  rule on procedural and substantive issues of the hearing  determine the admissibility of evidence and testimony all of which must have a direct bearing on the issue considered by the hearing officer according to the evidentiary standard for administrative agencies the new mexico rules of evidence will be liberally interpreted  and issue findings of fact and conclusions of law the hearing will be recorded by a certified court reporter in most cases the order of presentation of the case will be as follows a opening statement the city will present its statement of issues followed by the grievant b presentation of the citys case witnesses for the city may be called and questioned the grievant will have the opportunity to crossexamine witnesses the hearing officer may also question witnesses on matters relating to the witness testimony c presentation of the grievants case following the same format as the citys presentation and the city will have the opportunity to crossexamine the grievants witnesses d following the grievants presentation the city may offer rebuttal testimony e closing statements the city will present first followed by the grievant closing statements will be limited to ten 10 minutes and will at a minimum contain a request for the desired outcome the city may make a final statement following the grievants closing statement 8 the parties shall stipulate to the facts and issues to the greatest extent possible prior to the hearing prior to the hearing the parties shall prepare copies of all exhibits and evidence which are expected to be presented the parties shall stipulate to exhibits to the extent possible and bring to the hearing enough copies for the hearing officer and the opposing party at least five working days prior to the hearing all parties must submit to the hearing officer a statement of the issues to be heard a witness list and a complete list of documents to be admitted as evidence 9 witnesses will not be admitted to the hearing room until called upon to testify except those required to be present the grievant the grievants legal counsel if any the citys legal counsel the department manager and the city manager 10 the personnel hearing officer shall prepare written findings and conclusions and submit them to the parties within thirty 30 calendar days of the date of the hearing the hearing officer may uphold modify or reverse the decision of the city manager and may reinstate the employee and award only back pay and benefits the decision of the personnel hearing officer is binding and subject to review by petition for writ of certiorari by either party to the tenth judicial district of the state of new mexico the record of the proceedings will be retained by the city managers office or the certified court reporter for a period of not less than three years from the hearing date along with all of the physical evidence admitted by the hearing officer the verbal transcript shall be transcribed only in the case of appeal to the district court by one of the respective parties  8142014   open door communications to promote open twoway communication between employees and management and to encourage employees to come forward in an atmosphere of courtesy and cooperation to develop mutually beneficial solutions to problems or complaints which may affect the employee in the course of their employment and which can improve the citys operations the city of tucumcari provides an open door policy the open door is for positive communication flow as well as for addressing concerns this policy also provides employees the opportunity to voice complaints concerning alleged improper actions of supervisors or management the employee is required to begin all discussions under this policy with their immediate supervisor the city believes that employees have the individual right to speak for themselves and respectfully voice their concerns supervisors are responsible for listening with respect and assisting employees whenever possible the existence of this policy is to provide communication and promote problem solving the existence of this policy does not give the employee an independent right to pursue a grievance  8142014   driving requirements the city of tucumcari has developed this policy to ensure that all employees who are required to operate a motor vehicle in the course of their duties do so in a safe and courteous manner and to remain in compliance with the citys insurance requirements all employees who must operate their own vehicle or a cityowned vehicle to conduct the citys business must possess a valid new mexico state drivers license active automobile insurance and a safe driving record the city may request a copy of a dmv report for any employee or prospective employee prior to hiring and periodically after employment as determined to be appropriate by the city managers office if their job responsibilities include driving for the city 1 in order to obtain a position with the city an employee must possess a valid new mexico drivers license and attend a city of tucumcari driver safety education class annually 2 employees who drive for the city must immediately inform their supervisor if their state issued drivers license is expired suspended or revoked 3 employees driving privately owned vehicles for the citys business purposes must personally possess and provide at a minimum proof of liability insurance for the vehicle they will be operating  8142014   external communications all external communication with the press or other media outlets will be coordinated city managers office to maintain accuracy and ensure the interests of the city are correctly represented an individual employee may not represent the citys position or view to the general public without specific assignment and authority to do so information regarding city policies issues or problems must not be discussed with other organizations the media or the general public except by those individuals who are directed to communicate such information at the appropriate times  8142014   confidentiality employees of the city of tucumcari will by the nature of their duties have access to confidential information regarding employees citizen customers competitive bids andor awards etc confidential information learned by employees in the course of performing their duties for the city shall not be discussed with anyone who does not have a need to know transmittal of information within or outside of the city that would serve no useful purpose and could be harmful to the interests of the city or to fellow employees including information regarding promotions terminations demotions complaints or charges against an individual employee salary information certain procurement transactions of the city including the purchase acquisition or disposal of real property or water rights deliberations in connection with an administrative adjudicatory proceeding personal medical information letters of reference law enforcement records that reveal confidential sources methods or information on individuals accused but not charged with a crime etc is not permitted except as expressly allowed by law people who may have a need to know confidential information are employees citizen customers or vendors who require confidential information to properly perform assigned tasks related to the provision of services wellbeing or the growth and development of the city this will include management and administrative personnel who have supervisory and oversight responsibilities for services provided and service staff whose required activities provide a direct ability to benefit the customer citizens have a right to know information about city operations and activities that does not disclose personal employee information or violate other established confidentiality policies that protect the citys interests there is a formal process for citizens to follow to request information that is important to understanding the citys operations and finances this confidentiality policy is not intended to nor does it in any way interfere with a citizens rights under the open meetings act nmsa 1978 or the inspection of public records act 1424 nmsa 1978 all information regarding employees and citizen customers is to be held in the strictest of confidence and only shared when there is a legitimate business need with those other employees or business associates of the city who have a need to know the information in order to provide services to the clients employees may be required to obtain citizen customer permission to disclose information to other employees or to outside parties depending upon the situation and the information involved employees or former employees privileged to know confidential information in the course of performing their duties are expected to maintain the confidentiality of that information during and after their employment in the case of employees who terminate any confidential documents in their possession will be returned to the city upon termination  8142014   personal and professional conduct the city of tucumcari expects its employees to uphold the values and mission of the city of tucumcari by maintaining a professional and teamoriented work environment representing the city in the workplace and in public in a manner that represents the citys values of hard work and exceptional public service city employees are constantly in the public eye  consequently it is important that every employee present the best possible image to the public employees should always be neat and clean and dressed in clothing suitable for their work assignments when uniforms are available for employees they must be worn while an employees conduct after hours is generally considered his or her personal business serious personal misconduct may adversely affect public confidence in the city government and its employees personal misconduct that bears a reasonable nexus to the employees job responsibilities and that affects the employees ability to effectively perform their job whether performance or loss of public confidence andor unfavorable publicity to the city may result in corrective disciplinary action up to and including termination examples of such misconduct include but are not limited to domestic violence or driving while under the influence employees are expected to conduct themselves at all times with professionalism and courtesy every employee is a representative of the city and is expected to present the highest professional and ethical behavior at all times to customers vendors and any other associates of the city see of interest section for additional guidance all business relationships involving employees customers vendors guests or others will be conducted with mutual respect and in a manner that is conducive to achieving the citys goals and that upholds the citys beliefs and values outside relationships activities andor employment by any individual engaged or employed by the city shall not in any way jeopardize the confidentiality business or employment responsibilities programbusiness interests or good standing of the city city employees are encouraged to exercise their political rights as citizens vote as they may choose support candidates of their choice and express their political opinions however political activities must take place outside of working hours and away from city offices employees may not use their official position with the city to endorse any candidate for office or influence the outcome of an election if any employee is unsure as to whether certain behavior is considered unprofessional conduct they are encouraged to ask their immediate supervisor violations of this policy may result in disciplinary action up to and including discharge see disciplinary action section  8142014   conflict of interest in order to prevent a conflict of interest or the appearance of a conflict of interest every employee will maintain professional conduct in line with the citys mission and values no employee shall use his or her position with the city for purposes that are motivated by a desire for private financial gain for themselves or others such as immediate family business associates or other similar ties activities prohibited include but are not limited to the following  accepting any gifts gratuities or tips from clients vendors or other business associates of the city for any value greater than twentyfive dollars $2500 in no case are gifts allowed that may interfere with an employees ability to make sound business decisions  receiving or accepting any fee or gratuity for negotiating contracts or other agreements  accepting compensation from acting as a board member for or having other business relations with consultants and vendors of the city without prior written permission by the city manager  offering favorable contract terms in order to obtain a personal benefit which may or may not include monetary benefit from any person or business entity  any use of your official authority or duties that results in unwarranted personal gain or provides an improper benefit to friends or relatives the city manager shall investigate any allegation of conflict of interest and if the allegation is confirmed shall work together with the supervisor to determine the most appropriate administrative action in accordance with the corrective counseling and disciplinary action policy in the cases where the employee who commits the violation is employed with grantrelated funds the supervisor shall if requested or required report the actions taken to the appropriate grantor official city employees may not also hold positions as city board of commissioners member if an employee is elected or appointed to a commission seat the employee shall resign from their job or decline the appointment any employee elected to municipal office shall resign from the employ of the city  8142014   personnel records the city managers office will maintain a system of confidential personnel records a personnel records folder will be created at the time of hire and maintained on each employee all personnel records pertaining to an employee will be kept in secure files within the city managers office file access access to all personnel files is restricted to authorized employees on a need to know basis personnel files are the property of the city and may not be removed from the city managers office the city manager will determine who has a need to know employees should be aware that information contained in employee personnel files including employee applications is subject to disclosure under the inspection of public records act pursuant to nmsa section 1421 except for records pertaining to physical or mental examinations and medical treatment letters of reference and letters or memoranda that are matters of opinion any employee may arrange to see hisher personnel financial and restricted access files this can be done by contacting the city managers office and arranging an appointment the file may not be removed from the office but a copy of documents signed by the employee can be made available with the courtesy of a request in advance once copies have been issued to the employee the employee assumes the responsibility for maintaining the confidentiality of the information  8142014   safe workplace it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a safe workplace for its employees that is free of known and reasonably foreseeable hazards safety in the work place is everyones business and requires the personal commitment of each employee the following represent the major guidelines for maintaining a workplace free of recognizable hazards  the city will take all necessary measures to maintain a safe and healthy working environment that is as free from recognizable hazards as is possible the immediate supervisor is responsible for the safety of the employees working for himher the supervisor is responsible for identifying known or reasonably foreseeable hazards in a work area and educating employees to those hazards  the city has issued a safety manual which describes safe work processes and rules that will be applicable to the particular work being done by the various programs in work areas throughout the city employees must familiarize themselves with the safety manual and supervisors must ensure that employees contractors and visitors follow its provisions  every employee must take responsibility for working safely staying alert to potential hazards in the work environment reporting hazards or unsafe conditions to their supervisor and wearing the personal protective equipment required for the work they are doing  employees who behave in an unsafe way or who jeopardize the safety of themselves or others action or inaction or who fail to follow the established safety procedures will be subject to corrective disciplinary action  wellorganized and clean work areas are essential to maintaining a safe and hazardfree work environment every employee is responsible for maintaining the citys premises in a neat orderly and clean fashion  repairs to equipment and electrical lines must be made by qualified personnel only  employees must use proper lifting techniques whenever moving boxes furniture equipment supplies or other material  employees who operate a motor vehicle in the conduct of city business are expected to obey all applicable traffic laws  seat belts must be worn at all times while driving or riding in any motor vehicle while on city business  employees are prohibited from using a cellphone including texting while driving a vehicle on city business a driver who must use a cellphone must first pull over to the side of the road in a safe location out of traffic  all accidents near misses and incidents where someone could have been injured must be reported to the supervisor  employees who observe an unsafe condition should report the condition to the immediate supervisor as soon as possible if the condition persists the employee should state the problem in writing and submit it to the department manager  employees must immediately report all workrelated accidents injuries and illnesses no matter how minor to their supervisor for evaluation and appropriate documentation when an employee is injured the supervisor will notify the department head the safety department and the city managers office  if an injury requires medical attention beyond simple first aid the city will arrange for medical care and the injured employee will be transported to the authorized health care provider or hospital for all onthejob injuries whether or not medical attention is rendered the supervisor must complete the supervisors first report of injury form the city managers office has the appropriate forms the completed form will be returned to the city managers office  8142014   secure workplace it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a safe and secure work environment for city employees contractors will not be permitted to work unsupervised and will not be allowed free access or passwords to either the building or the voice or data communications network when entering the building employees should immediately notify their supervisor if they notice any unusual conditions such as unlocked doors that should be locked unattended or unclaimed packages or bags lying around missing equipment or other materials or other unusual conditions it is the citys policy to require all visitors to check in at the front desk before entering the work area it is also the policy of the city that the presence of visitors is primarily intended as a part of ongoing functions and work requirements while nonwork related visitors may be allowed this will only be to the extent that productivity is maintained employees are hereby notified that the city reserves the right to search workstations lockers desks and cityowned vehicles for illegal drugs alcohol weapons and stolen property referred to collectively as contraband to ensure the safety and security of its employees and property lunch boxes briefcases purses coats toolboxes and other personal property of employees and their contents may be searched in certain circumstances in accordance with applicable regulations by law enforcement officers procedure 1 all visitors must receive authorization to enter the office area 2 visitors must indicate who their host is in the city  the host will be called to receive the visitor visitors will be escorted by their host at all times while on premises 3 it is the responsibility of every employee to ensure that the presence of visitors does not interfere with productivity in the workplace department management may decide to decline the presence of visitors if in the judgment of the department management the presence of the visitors causes disruption of productivity in the workplace 4 when there is reasonable cause to believe that an employee has brought contraband onto city premises the city may conduct a search for the suspect items any contraband in plain view may be confiscated immediately 5 when contraband is not in plain view but there is reasonable cause to believe that the item is on city property city management will notify the employee that a search has been conducted or will be conducted 6 employees have no reasonable expectation of privacy in and may not withhold permission for searches of citysupplied equipment or furniture including desks lockers toolboxes computer systems email accounts and city owned vehicles  8142014   antidiscrimination and sexual harassment policy it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a workplace free from harassment of any sort including but not limited to intimidation threats physical assault stalking badgering insults bullying and sexual harassment harassment includes any repeated unwanted behavior that substantially prevents the person being harassed from performing his or her duties threatens or intimidates the receiver or produces an uncomfortable or hostile work environment the city will not tolerate any harassment or disrespect shown to an employee based on their sex race age sexual orientation religion or disability the city will also not tolerate harassment of an employee by nonemployees in the workplace any employee who experiences harassment by a nonemployee or who observes harassment of an employee by a nonemployee should immediately notify their supervisor and if the employee believes circumstances warrant also contact the city managers office management will take appropriate action to ensure the safety of its employees harassment of the citys citizen customers or vendors by city employees is also prohibited harassment is a form of discrimination for this purpose the term harassment includes slurs jokes other offensive remarks and physical conduct sexual harassment the equal employment opportunity commission has adopted guidelines which state that unwelcome sexual advances requests for sexual favors and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature constitute sexual harassment when 1 submission to the conduct is an explicit or implicit term or condition of an individuals employment  2 the submission to or rejection of the conduct by an individual is the basis for any employment decision affecting that individual  or 3 the conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individuals work performance or creating an intimidating hostile or offensive working environment a hostile work environment may be one where crude or vulgar language is used jokes of a sexual nature are told comments are made that demean an individual based on gender unwelcome nicknames such as honey or sweetie are used or photographs calendars magazines books etc of nude or partially nude individuals are disseminated retaliation against any employee by another employee or by management for using the provisions of this policy is prohibited prohibited retaliation includes but is not limited to demotion suspension failure to make employment recommendations impartially adversely affecting working conditions or otherwise denying any employment benefits procedure 1 the first step to resolving a problem is for the employee to communicate directly with the offending person to let them know what the offending behavior is and that it is unwanted the employee should take care to document the incidents of harassment and the steps taken toward resolution 2 if direct discussion is not practical or safe or the situation is not satisfactorily resolved by the employee and the offending person then it is imperative that the behavior perceived as harassment be reported as soon as possible to the city manager andor the human resources director this immediacy allows for swift investigation action and resolution notification of the problem is essential 3 it is the responsibility of the employee to make this report as management cannot investigate or remedy situations of which they are not aware 4 once the city manager or human resources has been notified of a harassment problem the employees supervisor will be notified unless the supervisor is one of the offending parties all complaints will be treated seriously and will be investigated as promptly and thoroughly as possible 5 any employee found investigation to be violating this policy will be subject to corrective disciplinary action see corrective disciplinary action policy 6 the city prohibits employees from hindering internal investigations 7 all reported complaints of harassment will be treated with as much confidentiality as possible consistent with the citys confidentiality policy and the need to conduct an adequate investigation while protecting the privacy of those involved  8142014   antiviolence it is the policy of the city of tucumcari to provide a safe violencefree workplace workplace violence will not be tolerated examples of workplace violence include but are not limited to the following  all threats or acts of violence including intimidation harassment andor coercion occurring on the citys premises regardless of the relationship between the city and the parties involved in the incident  all threats or acts of violence including intimidation harassment andor coercion occurring off the citys premises involving someone who is acting as a city representative  all threats or acts of violence including intimidation harassment andor coercion occurring off the citys premises involving an employee of the city if the threats or acts affect the legitimate interests of the city  any acts or threats of violence including intimidation harassment andor coercion resulting in the conviction of an employee of the city or of an individual performing services for the city on a contract or temporary basis under any criminal code provision relating to violence or threats of violence which adversely affect the legitimate mission and values of the city specific examples of conduct which may be considered threats or acts of violence including intimidation harassment andor coercion include but are not limited to the following  hitting or pushing an individual  threatening an individual or hisher family friends associates or property with harm  the intentional destruction or threat of destruction of cityowned or employeeowned property  harassing or threatening phone calls  harassing surveillance or stalking  the suggestion or intimation that violence is appropriate  unauthorized possession or inappropriate use of firearms or weapons  assault or battery assault includes the threat of violence not necessarily the act battery is the enactment of violence  unauthorized use inappropriate display or presentation of any type of weapon that serves to intimidate threaten or cause fear violations of this policy by any employee on the citys property by any employee acting as a representative of the city while off the citys property may lead to corrective disciplinary action up to and including discharge andor legal action as appropriate for instances involving actions by nonemployees the city may forcibly remove the individual institute a restraining order or other legal means as necessary to ensure a safe workplace the city prohibits retaliation against any employee by another employee for reporting an incident under this policy prohibited retaliation includes but is not limited to demotion suspension failure to make employment recommendations impartially adversely affecting working conditions or otherwise denying any employment benefit procedure 1 every employee and every person on the citys property is encouraged to report incidents of workplace violence of which he or she is aware to the proper authorities 2 the report should also be given to the city managers office the reporting individuals immediate supervisor or another member of
